articles.headline: Trump’s Truth Social Is Poised to Join a Crowded Field
articles.snippet: Truth Social, the former president’s hard-right alternative to Twitter, could open its doors next month. But as businesses go, outrage may not be the best moneymaker.
articles.abstract: Truth Social, the former president’s hard-right alternative to Twitter, could open its doors next month. But as businesses go, outrage may not be the best moneymaker.
articles.lead_paragraph: For months, former President Donald J. Trump has promoted Truth Social, the soon-to-be-released flagship app of his fledging social media company, as a platform where free speech can thrive without the constraints imposed by Big Tech.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Ryan Mac

articles.headline: Kazakhstan’s Internet Shutdown Offers Lessons for Russia-Ukraine Crisis
articles.snippet: Control of the internet is increasingly part of any modern conflict.
articles.abstract: Control of the internet is increasingly part of any modern conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Almaty, Kazakhstan’s largest city, spiraled into chaos last month over rising energy costs and anger at the government, the country’s leaders took a drastic step to quell protests: They blocked the internet.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano, Paul Mozur and Valerie Hopkins

articles.headline: Material Recovered From Trump by Archives Included Classified Information
articles.snippet: The former president, who assailed Hillary Clinton in 2016 for her handling of sensitive material, was confirmed by the National Archives to have taken classified documents with him when he left office.
articles.abstract: The former president, who assailed Hillary Clinton in 2016 for her handling of sensitive material, was confirmed by the National Archives to have taken classified documents with him when he left office.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The National Archives confirmed on Friday that it had found classified information among material that President Donald J. Trump had taken with him to his home in Florida when he left office last year and that it had consulted with the Justice Department about the matter.
articles.byline: By Luke Broadwater and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Rates Are Rising. You Want a House. What Will Happen Next?
articles.snippet: A strange set of (you guessed it, pandemic-influenced) circumstances makes this a tough market to assess. Here are four questions and answers that can help.
articles.abstract: A strange set of (you guessed it, pandemic-influenced) circumstances makes this a tough market to assess. Here are four questions and answers that can help.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s what you think you want most in the world. It costs more than nearly anything else you’ll ever buy. The price may have risen over $50,000 last year. And now, here you are, trying to figure out what the machinations of the Federal Reserve might mean for you and your home purchase.

articles.headline: CNN Executive Was Ousted After Discussing Interview Topics With Governor
articles.snippet: An internal investigation found that a top executive, Allison Gollust, had extensive communications with then-Gov. Andrew Cuomo.
articles.abstract: An internal investigation found that a top executive, Allison Gollust, had extensive communications with then-Gov. Andrew Cuomo.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a Saturday in March 2020, as Covid-19 was invading the United States, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo went on CNN for a live interview. Among other topics, he was asked about a possible government-enforced quarantine of New York that had been floated by President Donald J. Trump.
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum, John Koblin and Emily Steel

articles.headline: Biden Says Putin Has Chosen ‘Catastrophic’ War Over Diplomacy
articles.snippet: President Biden spoke amid fears that Russia was setting the stage for an invasion that could ignite the biggest conflict in Europe in decades.
articles.abstract: President Biden spoke amid fears that Russia was setting the stage for an invasion that could ignite the biggest conflict in Europe in decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden said on Friday that the United States has intelligence showing that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has made a final decision to reject diplomatic overtures and invade Ukraine, in what Mr. Biden said would be a “catastrophic and needless war of choice” in Eastern Europe.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Valerie Hopkins, Marc Santora and Ivan Nechepurenko

articles.headline: Fringe Scheme to Reverse 2020 Election Splits Wisconsin G.O.P.
articles.snippet: False claims that Donald J. Trump can be reinstalled in the White House are picking up steam — and spiraling further from reality as they go.
articles.abstract: False claims that Donald J. Trump can be reinstalled in the White House are picking up steam — and spiraling further from reality as they go.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — First, Wisconsin Republicans ordered an audit of the 2020 election. Then they passed a raft of new restrictions on voting. And in June, they authorized the nation’s only special counsel investigation into 2020.

articles.headline: Pandemic’s Economic Impact Is Easing, but Aftershocks May Linger
articles.snippet: States are lifting mask mandates, and demand is bouncing back quickly after Omicron. Supply constraints are proving harder to escape.
articles.abstract: States are lifting mask mandates, and demand is bouncing back quickly after Omicron. Supply constraints are proving harder to escape.
articles.lead_paragraph: The pandemic’s grip on the economy appears to be loosening. Job growth and retail spending were strong in January, even as coronavirus cases hit a record. New York, Massachusetts and other states have begun to lift indoor mask mandates. California on Thursday unveiled a public health approach that will treat the coronavirus as a manageable long-term risk.

articles.headline: In Ukraine Crisis, the Looming Threat of a New Cold War
articles.snippet: If he invades, President Vladimir V. Putin is inviting a new global struggle with the West. He should think about how the last one ended, analysts say.
articles.abstract: If he invades, President Vladimir V. Putin is inviting a new global struggle with the West. He should think about how the last one ended, analysts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Vladimir Pozner was an English-language Soviet propaganda editor in Moscow in 1962, a job that gave him rare access to American newspapers and magazines. That allowed him to follow the Cuban Missile Crisis outside the Soviet media filter, and sense a world at the brink of war.

articles.headline: Who Is Behind QAnon? Linguistic Detectives Find Fingerprints
articles.snippet: Using machine learning, separate teams of computer scientists identified the same two men as likely authors of messages that fueled the viral movement.
articles.abstract: Using machine learning, separate teams of computer scientists identified the same two men as likely authors of messages that fueled the viral movement.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Shelling Escalates in Ukraine as Thousands Flee, Fearing Attack
articles.snippet: Western leaders repeat calls for a diplomatic resolution to the crisis. Russia fires missiles in a blunt warning of where the conflict could lead.
articles.abstract: Western leaders repeat calls for a diplomatic resolution to the crisis. Russia fires missiles in a blunt warning of where the conflict could lead.
articles.lead_paragraph: Artillery fire escalated sharply in eastern Ukraine on Saturday and thousands of residents fled the region in chaotic evacuations — two developments rife with opportunities for what the United States has warned could be a pretext for a Russian invasion.

articles.headline: New Twist in Pandemic’s Impact on Schools: Substitutes in Camouflage
articles.snippet: Deployed to classrooms in New Mexico to help with crippling staff shortages, National Guard troops are employing their informal motto, “Semper Gumby” — Always Flexible.
articles.abstract: Deployed to classrooms in New Mexico to help with crippling staff shortages, National Guard troops are employing their informal motto, “Semper Gumby” — Always Flexible.
articles.lead_paragraph: ESTANCIA, N.M. — The chorus of small voices ringing from a third-grade classroom on a recent morning signaled how far Estancia Elementary School had come in resuming a sense of normalcy after the latest coronavirus surge.
articles.byline: By Erica L. Green and Adria Malcolm

articles.headline: The Next Affordable City Is Already Too Expensive
articles.snippet: In Spokane, Wash., home prices jumped 60 percent in the past two years. The increase is fueled by buyers fleeing the boom in cities like Austin. Who will have to flee next?
articles.abstract: In Spokane, Wash., home prices jumped 60 percent in the past two years. The increase is fueled by buyers fleeing the boom in cities like Austin. Who will have to flee next?
articles.lead_paragraph: Maybe it was the date night when he and his wife spent two hours driving 19 miles to dinner, or the homeless encampment down the street, or the fact that homes were so expensive that his children could never afford to live near him.

articles.headline: With Olympics Closing Ceremony, China Celebrates a Joyless Triumph
articles.snippet: The Games ended without disaster but overshadowed by a doping scandal, rising tensions in Europe and anxiety over the future of the sporting movement.
articles.abstract: The Games ended without disaster but overshadowed by a doping scandal, rising tensions in Europe and anxiety over the future of the sporting movement.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — All along, Chinese officials insisted that the Olympics were not about politics, but rather sports. In the end, controversy and scandal haunted those, too.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Kevin Draper

articles.headline: Vast Leak Exposes How Credit Suisse Served Strongmen and Spies
articles.snippet: Leaked data on more than 18,000 accounts shows that the Swiss bank missed or ignored red flags.
articles.abstract: Leaked data on more than 18,000 accounts shows that the Swiss bank missed or ignored red flags.
articles.lead_paragraph: The client rosters of Swiss banks are among the world’s most closely guarded secrets, protecting the identities of some of the planet’s richest people and clues into how they accumulated their fortunes.
articles.byline: By Jesse Drucker and Ben Hubbard

articles.headline: How They Did It: Sandy Hook Families Gain Long-Awaited Legal Wins
articles.snippet: After early defeats in Congress, relatives of those lost in the 2012 shooting fought on, besting a renowned gun maker and an infamous conspiracy theorist.
articles.abstract: After early defeats in Congress, relatives of those lost in the 2012 shooting fought on, besting a renowned gun maker and an infamous conspiracy theorist.
articles.lead_paragraph: The image stopped him cold. Josh Koskoff, a Connecticut lawyer, was scanning crime scene photos of the 2012 Sandy Hook school shooting when he noticed “taped mags” on a classroom floor, two ammunition magazines crudely duct-taped together to speed reloading.

articles.headline: Blitzkrieg or Minor Incursion? Putin’s Choice Could Determine World Reaction.
articles.snippet: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia may be looking for fissures in the Western alliance, which so far has been united against him.
articles.abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia may be looking for fissures in the Western alliance, which so far has been united against him.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUNICH — When President Biden declared on Friday he was convinced President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia had decided to attack Ukraine “in the coming week, in the coming days,” the skeptics among American allies suddenly fell quiet. Hours before, Mr. Biden had informed them that American intelligence agencies had just learned that the Kremlin had given the order for Russian military units to proceed with an invasion.

articles.headline: If War Flames in Ukraine, These 2 Little Enclaves May Be the Spark
articles.snippet: Russian-backed separatists in the Luhansk and Donetsk regions once got just passing attention. They loom much larger now as many fear what may come next in Ukraine.
articles.abstract: Russian-backed separatists in the Luhansk and Donetsk regions once got just passing attention. They loom much larger now as many fear what may come next in Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: STANYTSIA LUHANSKA, Ukraine — People pass the bare-bones checkpoint dragging wheeled suitcases along the muddy pavement, crossing one of the starkest political divides in Europe today.

articles.headline: Black Farmers Fear Foreclosure as Debt Relief Remains Frozen
articles.snippet: Lawsuits from white farmers have blocked $4 billion of pandemic aid that was allocated to Black farmers in the American Rescue Plan.
articles.abstract: Lawsuits from white farmers have blocked $4 billion of pandemic aid that was allocated to Black farmers in the American Rescue Plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For Brandon Smith, a fourth-generation cattle rancher from Texas, the $1.9 trillion stimulus package that President Biden signed into law nearly a year ago was long-awaited relief.

articles.headline: Crypto Scammers’ New Target: Dating Apps
articles.snippet: “Everything was a lie,” said one woman lured into a recent scam.
articles.abstract: “Everything was a lie,” said one woman lured into a recent scam.
articles.lead_paragraph: The man from the dating app Hinge checked all of Tho Vu’s boxes.
